audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a brief intro tune featuring upbeat electronic music. A male speaker then introduces himself and the topic of the video: creating a UWP application. The speaker provides an overview of the video's content, which includes using the design surface in Blend, modifying controls and their templates, and using adaptive triggers. The music fades out as the speaker prepares to start the demonstration in Blend.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the use of Blend and Visual Studio, noting that while either could be used for the tasks he demonstrates, he prefers Blend due to his experience and comfort. He concludes that people can choose their preferred application. The audio consists only of spoken content.

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a program named "Blend" and stating that the design surface initially resembles a phone. He mentions that this can be changed by adjusting a value in the top left corner. He then describes how to select a different design surface, such as a "decent-sized desktop," and modifying the settings to fit all. He explains that this adjusts the design surface size conceptually, and he mentions he will address different device sizes later. The clip concludes with him stating that he is presently working with the artboard.

A male speaker began discussing the simplicity of "control creation," suggesting a "Hello world" example. He stated that control options are to the left of the artboard in Blend, and he demonstrated selecting a text block to drop it on the design surface. He commented that the default font appeared small due to being zoomed out but would change the font size to make it more visible. After resizing the font, he typed "Hello world" and clicked outside the text block to finalize the edit.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating he's ready to deploy his traditional "Hello World" application. He then describes clicking a button to achieve this. Next, the speaker congratulates the listener on creating their first "Hello World" application.

The clip begins with a male speaker shifting the conversation toward application customization. He decides to create an "OK button" for himself. He proceeds to describe dragging a button out and wanting to change the font size, indicating he does not remember exactly where that was. He decides to do a search for it.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing buttons in user interface design, suggesting the use of a "content command" instead of a text command for broader control. He explains that a button can include graphics or other controls, unlike a text box. He then states that he will "set the content of my button to just say okay." The speaker concludes by introducing what he refers to as the "default button" and transitions to discussing how to modify it using a "universal Windows application." During the speech, there is a brief musical interlude with no discernible genre or instrumentation.

A male speaker begins with an informative tone, describing fitting selection on a design surface for visibility. He details right-clicking a button and scrolling to edit a template, choosing to edit a copy rather than creating a blank button. The speaker explains that the object and timeline display the template, which can be used for any button in any application. He moves on to modifying the template's look, selecting the root grid and adding a rectangle behind a content presenter, clarifying that the presenter shows content for the button. The speaker mentions changing the rounding of the rectangle and resetting the background to achieve a desired button appearance.

The clip features a single male speaker discussing making fairly simple changes. He describes how he's modified the appearance of an "okay" button.  He explains how to scope back to the main document and "fit all."  He notes that it's cool to drag out another button. He details right-clicking, choosing "edit template," applying a resource, and picking a button style that he created. He then states, "Now, it'll go ahead and customize that control in exactly the same way," and explains how it allows him to give all his controls a consistent look.

A male speaker begins by outlining the purpose of using adaptive triggers to modify application layouts on desktops and phones. He then describes the steps, stating that he will go to the "states pane" and "create a state group". He mentions he will be "adding a couple adaptive triggers". One trigger will be "wide", and the other "narrow".

A male speaker describes editing and adapting a trigger by adding one and changing the minimum window width to "1024." He mentions a second trigger where he sets the minimum width to "320." He explains that he has told the system to examine the width of the application and adjust the controls' positions based on whether it is greater than "1024." If it is not greater, the system will drop down to the next adaptive trigger and move everything to that location.

A male speaker begins by saying "Let me show you what I mean" before describing the action of dragging buttons on screen to the left. He then says he will rotate a "hello world" label while holding the shift key, explaining this informs the system that he is working with a wider application, like the "full width of my screen", or over "1024 pixels or wider". As soon as the application is narrow, he wants to see the controls in a different position. To demonstrate, he plays the application locally. By default, the application is large, so everything will display in a wide layout. However, the default width is less than "1024" so it defaults to the narrow layout. As he makes the application wider, crossing the "1024 threshold," the speaker notes that everything moves to the wide position.

The clip begins with a single male speaker presenting a simple example, stating that controls move where you want them to, and that it gives you an idea of how to use adaptive triggers to change your UI, whether working on a phone, laptop, or other device. He concludes by saying "that's all there is to it."

The clip starts with someone speaking in a calm, informative tone, explaining the use of the design surface for UI creation and template modification. He notes the availability of the states panel in Blend and contrasts it with Visual Studio's code-level requirement for adaptive triggers, mentioning that IntelliSense can help. He then transitions to discussing debugging and deploying the application, preparing to look at the underlying business logic. As he concludes, music begins; an electronic track, perhaps for a trailer or an intro with an energetic but slightly suspenseful feel.
